title: Interrupting Shema for a king
vignette: While reciting Shema, one sees the ruling monarch approaching; failure to greet may provoke deadly punishment.

options.text: Continue Shema; do not interrupt sacred words.
Interrupt and greet to save one’s life.

title: Interrupting Shema for a revered teacher
vignette: A disciple meets his master mid-Shema. Must he break off to offer respectful greeting?

options.text: Do not interrupt; prayer takes precedence.

title: Employee’s prayer on the boss’s time
vignette: Labourers recite the Amida while on the employer’s clock.

options.text: Shorten it so as not to steal work time.

title: Praying astride a donkey
vignette: A traveller on a loaded donkey reaches prayer time. Proper devotion requires standing, but dismounting risks loss or danger.

options.text: Remain mounted and pray as best as possible.

title: Solo vs. communal Shema
vignette: One can recite Shema alone now at its optimal time, or delay to join a later minyan.

options.text: Wait and recite with the group.

title: Joining a Zimun vs. urgent business
vignette: After eating, companions form a blessing quorum. One diner has pressing work elsewhere.

options.text: Stay and join the group blessing.
Leave early to protect one’s livelihood.

title: Tefillin outside a latrine
vignette: One must enter a latrine while wearing tefillin. Removing them and leaving outside risks theft; bringing them in degrades holiness.

options.text: Leave them outside to preserve their sanctity.
